articles.headline: Apple Passes Microsoft as No. 1 in Tech
articles.snippet: Apple, which had been given up for dead a decade ago, is now the world’s most valuable technology company.
articles.abstract: Apple, which had been given up for dead a decade ago, is now the world’s most valuable technology company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Wall Street has called the end of an era and the beginning of the next one: The most important technology product no longer sits on your desk but rather fits in your hand.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Facebook Bows to Pressure Over Privacy
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief, said the new settings would make it easier for users to understand how much of their personal information was publicly accessible.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief, said the new settings would make it easier for users to understand how much of their personal information was publicly accessible.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Ever since Facebook was founded in 2004, Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive, has pushed its users to share more information about themselves. Time and again, users have pushed back, complaining that some new feature or setting on the site violated their privacy.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Rumors Are Realized in New App Phones
articles.snippet: Two new Kin app phones from Microsoft and the Incredible (yes, the Incredible) from HTC have arrived after months of rumors and leaks.
articles.abstract: Two new Kin app phones from Microsoft and the Incredible (yes, the Incredible) from HTC have arrived after months of rumors and leaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s all about the app phones these days, isn’t it?

articles.headline: Trampled in a Land Rush, Chinese Resist
articles.snippet: After resistance to development from property owners, reforms are working their way through the bureaucracy.
articles.abstract: After resistance to development from property owners, reforms are working their way through the bureaucracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When China’s land boom excited a frenzy of popular resistance late last year — including headline-grabbing suicides by people routed from their homes — Chinese policy makers finally proposed a solution: rules to protect citizens from unchecked development and to fairly compensate the evicted.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: California Puts Vote Overhaul on the Ballot
articles.snippet: Voters will decide on June 8 if they want to replace the primary system with one involving two rounds of voting.
articles.abstract: Voters will decide on June 8 if they want to replace the primary system with one involving two rounds of voting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In another indication of how frustrated voters have grown with politics as usual, California — home of initiative-happy democracy — is considering a radical overhaul.

articles.headline: In New Era of TV, Rival Hosts Drown Out King
articles.snippet: “Larry King Live,” far behind Rachel Maddow and Sean Hannity, is the last trace of a previous age of cable TV.
articles.abstract: “Larry King Live,” far behind Rachel Maddow and Sean Hannity, is the last trace of a previous age of cable TV.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest interview on television last week, with the Senate candidate Rand Paul, happened at 9 p.m. But regrettably for CNN’s Larry King, who used to rule that time slot by wooing newsmakers, the interview was booked by his higher-rated competitor, MSNBC’s Rachel Maddow.

articles.headline: In E. Coli Fight, Some Strains Are Largely Ignored
articles.snippet: As regulators focused on one virulent strain of E. Coli, six others are emerging as a serious threat to food safety.
articles.abstract: As regulators focused on one virulent strain of E. Coli, six others are emerging as a serious threat to food safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Public Enemy No. 1 for the food industry and its government regulators has been a virulent strain of E. coli bacteria that has killed hundreds of people, sickened thousands and prompted the recall of millions of pounds of hamburger, spinach and other foods.

articles.headline: Questions for Makers on Defects in Drugs
articles.snippet: Congress will try to learn why bits  of metal and other impurities were found in drugs made by two companies.
articles.abstract: Congress will try to learn why bits  of metal and other impurities were found in drugs made by two companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: For consumers who turned to drugstore house brands after the recall last month of liquid children’s Tylenol and other medicines made by a unit of Johnson & Johnson, there is yet more unsettling news.

articles.headline: BP Used Riskier Method to Seal Well Before Blast
articles.snippet: Days before the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil  rig, BP officials chose a type of casing that it knew was the riskier of two options, a BP document showed.
articles.abstract: Days before the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil  rig, BP officials chose a type of casing that it knew was the riskier of two options, a BP document showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several days before the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, BP officials chose, partly for financial reasons, to use a type of casing for the well that the company knew was the riskier of two options, according to a BP document.

articles.headline: U.S. Markets Rebound; S.&P. Rises 3.3%
articles.snippet: Investors focused on buying opportunities and reassuring comments from China on European debt.
articles.abstract: Investors focused on buying opportunities and reassuring comments from China on European debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once again, the stock market swung wildly on Thursday  only this time, it swung up, rather than down.
articles.byline: By Christine Hauser and David Jolly

articles.headline: BP Resumes Work to Plug Oil Leak After Facing Setback
articles.snippet: BP resumed pumping drilling fluid into a stricken oil well after stopping late Wednesday when engineers saw that too much of the fluid was escaping along with the leaking crude oil.
articles.abstract: BP resumed pumping drilling fluid into a stricken oil well after stopping late Wednesday when engineers saw that too much of the fluid was escaping along with the leaking crude oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  BP on Thursday night restarted its most ambitious effort yet to plug the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico, trying to revive hopes that it might cap the well with a “top kill” technique that involved pumping heavy drilling liquids to counteract the pressure of the gushing oil.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Pequot Capital and Its Chief Agree to Settle S.E.C. Suit for $28 Million
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. suit centered on allegations that a sizable bet by Pequot on Microsoft stock was based on inside information.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. suit centered on allegations that a sizable bet by Pequot on Microsoft stock was based on inside information.
articles.lead_paragraph: A tangled and protracted insider trading case that brought embarrassment to the Securities and Exchange Commission came to a close on Thursday when Arthur J. Samberg, a hedge fund industry giant, and Pequot Capital Management, the firm he founded, agreed to pay $28 million to settle fraud allegations.
